symptoms: **Profuse watery diarrhea with rice-water appearance** - up to 10-20 liters per day
**Painless, voluminous stools** (distinguishes from other dysenteries)
Severe vomiting and nausea (projectile vomiting)
**Rapid, severe dehydration** with sunken eyes and dry mouth
**Muscle cramps, especially in legs and abdomen** (pathognomonic sign)
**Skin loses elasticity** - pinched skin stays elevated for >2 seconds
**Little or no urine production** (oliguria/anuria)
**Thready, weak pulse** and low blood pressure
**No fever or minimal fever** (unlike other bacterial infections)
Shock and collapse in severe cases
**Symptoms appear rapidly: 2 hours to 5 days after infection**
distinctive_features: Rice-water stools without blood or mucus
Massive fluid loss without abdominal pain
Absence of fever in most cases
causes: Vibrio cholerae bacteria (O1 and O139 strains)
Contaminated tube wells and hand pumps
Food washed or prepared with contaminated water
Spreads rapidly in crowded areas with poor sanitation
prevention: Boil water for 1 minute or use water purification tablets
Drink only sealed bottled water when traveling
Avoid raw vegetables and street food during outbreaks
Use ORS packets available at all health centers
Maintain hand hygiene with soap and clean water
Oral cholera vaccine available at government health facilities

context.special_programs: Government runs special cholera control programs during monsoon

treatment: Immediate ORS and IV fluid replacement

symptoms: **High fever with step-ladder pattern** - gradually increases to 104°F over 3-4 days

**Severe headache and malaise** with body weakness
**Rose-colored rash on chest and abdomen** (appears in 30% cases, pathognomonic)
**Abdominal pain and bloating** with tenderness
**Constipation in adults, diarrhea in children** (age-specific pattern)
**Enlarged spleen** (splenomegaly - felt as left-side abdominal fullness)
**Loss of appetite and significant weight loss**
**Relative bradycardia** (slow pulse despite high fever)
Confusion and delirium in severe cases
Dry cough and sore throat
**Symptoms develop slowly: 1-4 weeks after consuming contaminated water/food**
causes: Contaminated water sources, especially community wells
Flies transferring bacteria from waste to food
prevention: Typhoid vaccination (Ty21a oral or Vi polysaccharide injectable) - available free at government centers
Drink boiled or properly treated water
Eat freshly cooked, hot food
Avoid street food and raw salads
Ensure proper waste disposal and sewerage
Regular hand washing with soap

treatment: Complete course of prescribed antibiotics (Ceftriaxone, Azithromycin)

symptoms: **High fever (102-105°F) lasting 1-3 weeks**

**Complete loss of appetite and nausea**
**Right upper abdominal pain and tenderness** (liver region)
**Dark yellow urine like strong tea** (pathognomonic)
**Clay-colored or chalk-white stools** (pathognomonic)
**Progressive yellowing of eyes and skin (jaundice)** - starts with eyes

**Generalized itching all over body** (cholestatic pruritis)
Vomiting and general malaise

**Symptoms last 2-8 weeks, more severe in adults over 30**
distinctive_features: Dark urine and pale stools before jaundice appears

Eating food washed with contaminated water
Raw or undercooked shellfish from contaminated water
prevention: Hepatitis A vaccination (Havrix/Vaqta - two doses, 6 months apart)
Boil water for drinking and food preparation
Avoid raw vegetables and fruits unless self-peeled
Maintain strict hand hygiene
Avoid swimming in contaminated water bodies
Use bottled water for teeth brushing when traveling

Proper sewage and waste management

Avoid raw or undercooked meat, especially pork
